summary: human syncytial virus (RSV) is an enveloped, single-stranded, negative-sense RNA virus whose genome of 15.2 kb contains 10 genes encoding a total of 11 proteins. they comprise three glycoproteins (F, G, and SH) inserted in the viral envelope, four proteins (N, P, L, and M2-1) associated with the ribonucleoprotein that are required for RNA synthesis, an additional protein (M) that forms the NS1 and NS2 proteins inhibit both IFN production and signaling. infected cells express high levels of ISGs, including ISG15 (20) ISG15 is a ubiquitin-like protein encoded by the interferon-stimulated gene 15. viruses have evolved mechanisms to counteract the ISG15 antiviral role. vaccinia virus E3 protein and influenza B virus NS1 protein bind ISG15. despite intensive research, neither a vaccine nor an effective antiviral therapy against RSV is currently available. hep-2 cell monolayers were infected with RSV at a multiplicity of infection (MOI) of 3 PFU per cell. cells were incubated with the viral inoculum in DMEM, 2% FBS (DMEM2) for 90 min at 37°C. after that time, the inoculum was removed and fresh DMEM2 was added. total RNA from mock-infected or infected cells was purified with the RNeasy minikit (Qiagen) and was reverse transcribed with the High-Capacity cDNA Archive kit (Applied Biosystems) gene expression was measured by quantitative RT-PCR with a step one instrument. RNA extraction, RSV nucleoprotein and ISG15 RNA levels were determined by qRT-PCR. similar to the pseudostratified epithelia, a high positive correlation was observed between RSV nucleoprotein and ISG15 expression. this suggests that ISG15 may play an antiviral role after natural infection. it has been claimed that ISG15 exerts its antiviral activity by conjugation to either viral or cellular proteins. it is possible that the ISG15 anti-RSV activity is mediated by direct ISGylation of viral and/or cellular proteins essential for virus replication. vaccinia virus E3 or influenza B virus NS1 proteins antagonize its antiviral effect. the same reasoning would apply if an RSV protein antagonizes any enzymes involved in ISGylation instead of ISG15 directly. the lack of ISG15 would destabilize USP18, leading to an increased response to type I IFN and viral resistance. ISG15 and UbE1L silencing had no effect on USP18 stabilization (55) but increased virus titers in IFN--treated cells. both increased RSV replication (Fig. 2A and 5D) while ISG15 and UbE1L silencing had opposite effects on RSV titers. positive correlation between RSV infection and ISG15 expression in human pseudostratified epithelia and in nasopharyngeal washes from infected children point to a role in RSV infections in vivo. in this setting, uninfected respiratory epithelial cells might acquire an antiviral status, which includes high levels of ISG15. in this scenario, ISG15 would play an important role in hindering RSV dissemination. to monitor RSV-induced inflammation, it is important to stress that ISG15 levels decreased between admission and discharge for every infant, reflecting the reduction in virus load and inflammation. in addition, data from nasopharyngeal washes from infants infected with RSV suggest that ISG15 may play an important role in RSV infection in vivo.
